leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Electrical systems and components are integral to most structures; therefore, it is necessary for the code to address their installation and protection. Structures depend on electricity for the operation of many life safety systems including fire alarm, smoke control and exhaust, fire suppression, fire command and communication systems. Since power supply to these systems is essential, Chapter 27 addresses where standby and emergency power must be provided.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter and NFPA 70 shall govern the design, construction, erection and installation of the electrical components, appliances, equipment and systems used in buildings and structures covered by this code. The Fire Code of New York State, the Property Maintenance Code of New York State and NFPA 70 shall govern the use and maintenance of electrical components, appliances, equipment and systems. The Existing Building Code of New York State and NFPA 70 shall govern the alteration, repair, relocation, replacement and addition of electrical components, appliances, or equipment and systems.

diagrams.title: Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 1
Electrical Panel - Work Space Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical panels shall be provided with a clear work space of 36" by 30" minimum from the floor up to a height of 6'-6". However, In existing dwelling units where the electrical service panel is less than 200 amperes, the height of the working space is allowed to be less than 6'-6".

diagrams.title: Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 3
Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 2
Indoor Dedicated Equipment Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where electrical service equipment, switchboards, switchgear, and panelboards are installed indoors the code requires the volume of space from the floor below to 6' above the equipment or the bottom of the structural ceiling, whichever is lower, to be dedicated to the electrical equipment. Foreign systems, such as the fire sprinkler are allowed above the dedicated space where the electrical equipment below is protected from condensation, leaks, or breaks that may occur within the foreign system. Non-structural ceilings, such as dropped or suspended ceilings, are allowed to encroach into the dedicated electrical space volume above the equipment.

diagrams.title: Clearances at Electrical Equipment
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The depth of working space in front of equipment that is less than 1000V is dependent on one of three conditions. Condition 1: Exposed live parts on one side of the working space. Condition 2: Exposed live parts on one side and grounded parts or concrete walls on the other. Condition 3: Exposed live parts on both sides.

Voltage ranges can be three ranges: 0-150 Volts to ground (all your 120/240 or 120/208 panels); 151-600 Volts to ground (all your 277/480 volt panels, transformers); 601-1000 Volts to ground (Higher voltage equipment).

Visualize that you are standing in front of a panel with exposed live parts. Then assess what is behind you, and what voltage the voltage of the equipment that is in front of you.

diagrams.title: Overhead Service Conductors: Above Roofs (< 1000V)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In general the service conductor must be 8' minimum above the surface of the roof. The code provides 5 exceptions to this requirement:
  1. If the roof will have pedestrian or vehicular traffic additional clearance as noted in section 230.24 (B) will apply
  2. Where the roof slope is 4:12 or greater and the voltage does not exceed 300 the vertical clearance from the roof to the conductor may be reduced to 3 ft.
  3. Above roof overhangs where the voltage does not exceed 300 the vertical clearance from the roof to the conductor may be reduced to 18 inches for the first 6 ft. of cable within the first 4 ft. horizontally provided the conductor terminates at a through roof raceway or approved support.
  4. The service clearance requirement above the roof edge does not apply to services attached to the side of a building
  5. Where the voltage does not exceed 300 and the roof area is guarded to isolate the conductors, 3 ft of clearance to the roof is permitted.

diagrams.title: Lighting Outlets - Guest Rooms / Suites
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The electrical code provides specific requirements, and exceptions, for guest rooms, which are generally Group R-1 occupancy, for transient individuals.

diagrams.title: Luminaires in Bathtub and Shower Areas
Electrical Working Space Conditions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The minimum required depth of working space in front of electrical equipment must meet the minimum distances specified in Table 110.26(A)(1) based on voltage to ground and the opposing surface per condition, unless exceptions requirements are met. Condition 1 provides that exposed live parts do not have live or grounded parts opposing it, or exposed live parts on both sides of working space are guarded by insulating materials. Condition 2 provides that exposed live parts are opposite grounded parts. Lastly, condition 3 provides that exposed live parts are opposite each other on both sides of working space.

diagrams.title: Service Conductors: Building Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Service conductors must maintain a 3' minimum clearance to an operable opening, porches, balconies, ladders, stairs, fire escapes or similar locations. A vertical clearance per section 230.24(B) shall be maintained above platforms, projections or surfaces that would otherwise permit contact with a conductor. Conductors may not obstruct or pass below openings used for entry or through which materials may be moved.

diagrams.title: Service Conductors: Clearances on Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Service conductors must maintain a 3' minimum clearance to an operable opening, porches, balconies, ladders, stairs, fire escapes or similar locations. A vertical clearance per section 230.24(B) shall be maintained above platforms, projections or surfaces that would otherwise permit contact with a conductor. Conductors may not obstruct or pass below openings used for entry or through which materials may be moved.

diagrams.title: Extension of Support Pads into Required Clearance
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical equipment support structures, such as concrete housekeeping pads, are allowed to encroach 6" into the required working space.

diagrams.title: Bored Holes and Nail Plates (NFPA 70)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The electrical code requires that cabling and wires that pass through framing be adequately protect from nail and screw penetration. Where the boring is less than 1-1/4" from the edge of a framing member, the code requires a 1/16" minimum thickness steel plate to protect the cabling or wires passing through the boring. The plate may be omitted where the cabling is protected by rigid metal conduit, intermediate metal conduit, rigid nonmetallic conduit, or electrical metallic tubing.

diagrams.title: High Rise: Emergency Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml: High-rise buildings have special requirements for emergency systems that must be in place. These systems include, full fire alarm system with additional smoke detection and emergency voice/alarm communications system, a standpipe system (permitted to be part of the sprinkler system), emergency responder radio coverage, a smoke removal system. All of these must be tied into the required fire command center. Standby and emergency power is required to run essential systems in case of emergency.

children.displayTitle: Section 2702 Emergency and Standby Power Systems

children.body: Emergency power systems and standby power systems shall comply with Sections 2702.1.1 through 2702.1.8.
Stationary emergency and standby power generators required by this code shall be listed in accordance with UL 2200.

Fuel lines supplying a generator set inside a high-rise building shall be separated from areas of the building other than the room the generator is located in by one of the following methods:
  1. A fire-resistant pipe-protection system that has been tested in accordance with UL 1489. The system shall be installed as tested and in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions, and shall have a rating of not less than 2 hours. Where the building is protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the required rating shall be reduced to 1 hour.
  2. An assembly that has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours. Where the building is protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the required fire-resistance rating shall be reduced to 1 hour.
  3. Other approved methods.

Emergency power systems and standby power systems required by this code or the Fire Code of New York State shall be installed in accordance with the Fire Code of New York State, NFPA 70, NFPA 110 and NFPA 111.

Emergency power systems shall automatically provide secondary power within 10 seconds after primary power is lost, unless specified otherwise in this code. Standby power systems shall automatically provide secondary power within 60 seconds after primary power is lost, unless specified otherwise in this code.

Emergency power systems and standby power systems shall be designed to provide the required power for a minimum duration of 2 hours without being refueled or recharged, unless specified otherwise in this code.
An uninterrupted source of power shall be provided for equipment where required by the manufacturer's instructions, the listing, this code or applicable referenced standards.
Emergency power systems shall be an acceptable alternative for installations that require standby power systems.

In Group I-2 occupancies located in flood hazard areas established in Section 1612.3, where new essential electrical systems are installed, and where new essential electrical system generators are installed, the systems and generators shall be located and installed in accordance with ASCE 24. Where connections for hookup of temporary generators are provided, the connections shall be located at or above the elevation required in ASCE 24.
Emergency and standby power systems shall be provided where required by Sections 2702.2.1 through 2702.2.20.
Essential electrical systems for ambulatory care facilities shall comply with Section 422.6.
Standby power shall be provided for elevators and platform lifts as required in Sections 1009.4.1, 1009.5, 3003.1, 3007.8 and 3008.8.

diagrams.title: Platform Lift Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Platform lifts may be used as part of an accessible means of egress under certain conditions. Inclined platform lifts may be used within dwelling units, but the stairways in which they exist must meet the requirements of Section 1011.2, Exception 3. Platform and stairway (inclined) chairlifts must meet the requirements of ASME A18.1.

diagrams.title: Vertical Platform Lifts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Vertical platform lifts, designed to provide short-distance vertical transportation for people with disabilities, typically include a platform that travels up and down along a vertical structure. These lifts can be either enclosed or non-enclosed, depending on the application and local code requirements. They can be installed both indoors and outdoors and are often used to provide access to raised entrances, stages, decks, or mezzanines.

Floor surfaces in platform lifts must comply with ADA Standards in sections 302 and 303. The controls for platform lifts should comply with ADA Standard section 309. Vertical platform lifts must not be attendant-operated, meaning they should allow for independent use by the person with a disability.

diagrams.title: Access. Means of Egress: Elevators
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings with four or more stories above or below the level of exit discharge, at least one accessible means of egress must be an elevator with standby power and emergency signaling devices. Designed to remain operational even when regular electrical service is lost, they are used by emergency responders to move personnel and fire-fighting equipment and to provide assisted rescue. Like all elevators, they are not to be used independently by building occupants in emergencies.

children.body: Standby power shall be provided for in-building 2-way emergency responder communication coverage systems required in Section 918 and the Fire Code of New York State. The standby power supply shall be capable of operating the in-building 2-way emergency responder communication coverage system at 100-percent system operation capacity for a duration of not less than 12 hours.

diagrams.title: Emergency Responder Radio Coverage (New Bldgs.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The construction materials used in buildings can significantly impede emergency responder radio signals and preclude effective communications during emergency operations. An Emergency Responder Communications Enhancement System (ERCES) is thus required in new buildings to support effective communication during emergency operations. Prior codes used the term Emergency Responder Radio Coverage System (ERRCS).

The code recognizes four specific code exceptions to ERCES installation, three of which require explicit approval of the fire code official. The fourth should also be confirmed by the fire code official. Exceptions:
  1. Subject to fire code official and building code official approval - a wired communications system meeting 907.2.13.2 may be used. Traditional firefighter phones, installed in accordance with NFPA 72 are a legacy technology that might meet this exception.
  2. If, after the building is constructed, radio testing within the building shows equal communication quality to that directly outside the building, the fire code official may approve the building without an ERCES.
  3. This exception recognizes that an ERCES that is always-on may conflict or interfere with operational elements (e.g. other radio signals, electronically sensitive equipment, etc.) of the building. In this instance, and with proper documentation, the fire code official may allow the system to "power up" upon activation of the fire alarm system or other approved automatically activated means.
  4. This exception recognizes that smaller buildings ($12,000 s.f.) are less likely to impede the public safety communications signal to an extent that will prevent effective interior communications.

children.body: Standby power shall be provided for emergency voice/alarm communication systems in accordance with NFPA 72.

Standby power shall be provided for common exhaust systems for domestic kitchens located in multistory structures as required in Section 505.5 of the Mechanical Code of New York State. Standby power shall be provided for common exhaust systems for clothes dryers located in multistory structures as required in Section 504.11 of the Mechanical Code of New York State and Section 614.11 of the Fuel Gas Code of New York State.
Emergency power shall be provided for exit signs as required in Section 1013.6.3. The system shall be capable of powering the required load for a duration of not less than 90 minutes.

diagrams.title: Exit Signs in R-1 Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In larger R-1 occupancies, both high and low exit signs are required. In a condition where a corridor has smoke, the smoke rises to the ceiling and can be so dark and thick that exit signs are obscured, and it could be hazardous to evacuate in a standing position. So that people can see exit signs obscured by smoke, the lower ones are provided.

diagrams.title: Exit Signs: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit signs are required to be posted at exit doors and in the direction of egress. These signs must be visible from any direction. These can be either internally, or externally, illuminated, and must be lighted and visible at all times. The "EXIT" lettering must be within the minimum dimensions of this code and is to be in a contrasting color from the background (typically this is red or green lettering on a white background).

diagrams.title: Exit Signs: Size Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit signs are required to be posted at exit doors and in the direction of egress. These signs must be visible from any direction. These can be either internally, or externally, illuminated, and must be lighted and visible at all times. The "EXIT" lettering must be within the minimum dimensions of this code and is to be in a contrasting color from the background (typically this is red or green lettering on a white background).

children.body: Emergency or standby power shall be provided for gas detection systems in accordance with the Fire Code of New York State.
Essential electrical systems for Group I-2 occupancies shall be in accordance with Section 407.11.
Emergency power shall be provided for power-operated doors and locks in Group I-3 occupancies as required in Section 408.4.2.
Emergency or standby power shall be provided in occupancies with hazardous materials where required by the Fire Code of New York State.
Emergency and standby power shall be provided in high-rise buildings as required in Section 403.4.8.
Standby power shall be provided for hydrogen fuel gas rooms as required by the Fire Code of New York State.

Standby or emergency power shall be provided in accordance with Section 5004.7 of the Fire Code of New York State where laboratory suites are located above the sixth story above grade plane or located in a story below grade plane.
Emergency power shall be provided for means of egress illumination as required in Section 1008.3. The system shall be capable of powering the required load for a duration of not less than 90 minutes.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Illumination:  Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit discharge pathways outside the building also require emergency exit illumination provisions. If egress is necessary in the dark to a designated area or public way, the pathway will need to be lit so occupants can safely egress the building. Note that in CA, special requirements exist in Section 1028.5 for exit discharge locations for Group E and for correctional facilities.

children.body: Standby power shall be provided for auxiliary inflation systems in permanent membrane structures as required in Section 3102.8.2. Standby power shall be provided for a duration of not less than 4 hours. Auxiliary inflation systems in temporary air-supported and air-inflated membrane structures shall be provided in accordance with Section 3103.9.4 of the Fire Code of New York State.
Emergency power shall be provided for semiconductor fabrication facilities as required in Section 415.11.11.
Standby power shall be provided for smoke control systems as required in Sections 404.7, 909.11, 909.20.7.2 and 909.21.5.

Standby power shall be provided for special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or folding doors as required in Section 1010.3.3. The standby power supply shall have a capacity to operate not fewer than 50 closing cycles of the door.
children.displayTitle: [F]  2702.2.18 Special Purpose Horizontal Sliding, Accordion or Folding Doors
children.titleText: Special Purpose Horizontal Sliding, Accordion or Folding Doors

children.body: Emergency and standby power shall be provided in underground buildings as required in Section 405.
Standby power shall be provided for mechanical exhaust ventilation systems in accordance with the Fire Code of New York State.

Required critical circuits shall be protected using one of the following methods:
  1. Cables, used for survivability of required critical circuits, that are listed in accordance with UL 2196 and have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
  2. Electrical circuit protective systems having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour. Electrical circuit protective systems are installed in accordance with their listing requirements.
  3. Construction having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
Emergency and standby power systems shall be maintained and tested in accordance with the Fire Code of New York State.
Where provided, lightning protection systems shall comply with Sections 2703.2 through 2703.3.

Lightning protection systems shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 780 or UL 96A. UL 96A shall not be utilized for buildings used for the production, handling or storage of ammunition, explosives, flammable liquids, flammable gases or other explosive ingredients including dust.
Where lightning protection systems are installed, surge protective devices shall also be installed in accordance with NFPA 70 and either NFPA 780 or UL 96A, as applicable.
All lightning protection systems on a building or structure shall be interconnected in accordance with NFPA 780 or UL 96A, as applicable.
Where required, buildings that include fossil fuel equipment and building systems shall comply with this section.
The minimum service load for the building shall be calculated for the future installation of electric equipment and appliances in accordance with NFPA 70.

Commercial cooking appliances shall be provided with a dedicated branch circuit rated and sized for an electric appliance with equivalent capacity and function. The branch circuit shall terminate within 6 feet (2 m) of the appliance with no obstructions. Both ends of the branch circuit shall be labeled with the words "For Future Electric Cooking Equipment" and be electrically isolated.

Laundromat equipment shall be provided with a raceway that is continuous between a junction box located within six feet (2 m) of the equipment and an electrical panel. The junction box, raceway and bus bar in the electrical panel shall be rated and sized to accommodate a branch circuit with sufficient capacity for electric equipment with equivalent capacity and function. The electrical junction box and electrical panel shall have labels stating, "For Future Electric Clothes Drying Equipment."

The construction documents shall provide details for additional electric infrastructure, including branch circuits, conduit, pre-wiring, panel capacity, and electrical service capacity, as well as interior and exterior spaces designated for future electric equipment.

Where required to be electrification ready by 19 NYCRR Part 1240, appliances, equipment and end-uses not covered by this section shall be provided with a branch circuit sized for an electric appliance, equipment or end use with an equivalent capacity and function, terminating within 6 feet (2 m) of the equipment with no obstructions.
